bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, March 25, 1923

div1.p: Carter informs Russell about a possible yellow fever epidemic in Colombia.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, March 25, 1923
div1.p:
Referring to Miss Read's letter of March 23rd.:--Please look at
Dr. Gorgas' report, in 1916, of the yellow fever alleged to have been
at the mines of Muso. Unless I am mistaken the report of the first
epidemic there was by Dr. Franco, who was absent from Bogota when we
were there. Both Gorgas and Whitmore were inclined to believe that
his report was faked and, prior to their examination and judging only
by internal evidence, neither Guiteras nor myself were disposed to
credit it as being made in good faith: The cases described (clinical
and autopsy findings) were, in our judgment, too absolutely book-cases.
This is simply to give you a pointer on Dr. Franco--if he be the same
man. It does not affect the nature of the present epidemic at Bucara-
manga reported by other men.

The description of the present epidemic of Bucaramanga is that of
yellow fever, although one could not on this alone deny the possibil-
ity of some spirochetosis, such as Guiteras found in Barbadoes and
' and Noc and Nogué in Senegal.
I note that he mentions the liver as being “palido,” not “amarillo.”

Lyster, Whitmore and Wrightson investigated this place in 1916.
There was a report--quite certainly correct--of a heavy epidemic of
yellow fever some years before with a very low mortality. I think all
this is stated in the Report on Colombia by the Commission of that year.
I remember writing about that epidemic, which quite-certainly came from
Maracaibo via Cúcuta.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, 2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
